lexUnit.name: couch.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: express in language of a specified style.

sentence.text: Sometimes the legislature does this when it imposes the duty by couching the duty in very clear , concrete , and specific terms .
The new-style sociobiologists , like the old-style ethologists , couch their arguments in highly anthropomorphic terms .
A major problem is that , despite the socially specific nature of their definition of Greek literacy , they still couch the argument in a way that tends towards technological determinism .
He couches everything in his own narrow terms of insecurity .

More generally , while there is no denying that leaders couch their statements in moral language , which seems to emphasize differences and minimize similarities , their actions often bear little resemblance to these moral pronouncements .
They then couch their message in terms with which their hearers will be familiar , seeking to move from the known to the unknown .
Lin was writing about his native village but he tried to evade the problems posed by autobiographical honesty by couching his story in the form of a novel .

Thus , we can not predict social events with absolute certainty and have to couch our forecasts in terms of probabilities , provided other factors do not change , which of course they can .

In the past , reasons for changing clubs have been couched in euphemistic terms , such as the need for a fresh challenge .

Second , the tone of such statements brooks no reply , and in any case the author 's argument is rarely couched in reasonable terms or supported by adequate evidence .

The court held that the guidance was defective because it was couched in mandatory terms , and inconsistent with the intended flexible nature of the scheme .
If something is couched in general terms then it is too vague and ill-defined .
The enquiry was couched in a low voice , almost a murmur , although it contained a hint of a rasp on the ` s " sounds .

There is frequently a " personal " element in poetry , but this element is couched within a highly formalised and conventional genre .
